TestCase.Name: IER-29 Air Tasking Order Distribution (Web-Hosting)

TestSteps.StepAction: Provider creates ATO following ADatP-3/APP-11 standards.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: ATO message is available for distribution following ADatP-3/APP-11 standards.

TestSteps.StepAction: Provider distributes ATO to consumer by posting ATO message on Portal site (Web-Hosting).
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: ATO message is posted to portal and available for downloading by subordinates units.

TestSteps.StepAction: Consumer is able to download ATO message from portal.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Consumer is able to download and open ATO message with no errors.

TestSteps.StepAction: Consumer feed/input ATO product into C2 System.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: C2 System able to consume and display ATO properly.

Tests.Name: Logging of events within the portal - SP5

TestCase.Name: Logging of events within the portal - SP5

TestSteps.StepAction: Run the portal in order to ensure at least one successful start of of the application.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The portal starts and is accessible by a user.

TestSteps.StepAction:
As a system administrator, log on to the portal host and check for the existance of either a log folder (including a filled in log file) **or** run a command returning the current events on the web server.
_(The utilization of the method depends on the implementation of logging in your mail server)_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The log folder should show at least one log file with an entry or the command output returns logged information.

TestSteps.StepAction: As a user log into the portal.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The portal is opened and displays the frontpage.

TestSteps.StepAction:
The sysadmin checks the latest log entry using the method in step 2.

_For details see SREQ 81_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
A new logging entry is available and reflect at least the following information.

* User identifier


* User IP / target IP
* Date and time of activity
* Event (in this case login)

Tests.Name: Web Hosting Profile: Web Feeds profiles (GEO RSS)

TestCase.Name: Web Hosting Profile: Web Feeds profiles (GEO RSS)

TestSteps.StepAction:
**Subscribe to the Participant feeds :**

1.  User will log into a workstation and open a web browser.
2.  User will enter the address of the Participant web page
3.  Main page of Participant web page contains a GEO RSS feed
4.  Subscribe to the feed
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
1.  Default web page will open
2.  Web page of the Participant will open
3.  1 feed visible
4.  Subscription successful

TestSteps.StepAction:
**Update content of the Subscripted feed Participant:**

1.  Participant will update content of all feeds
2.  User will check the feeds 
3.  User will unsubscribe from all feeds
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
1.  Participant  has updated connect on the web page
2.  User will see for each feed 1 update 
3.  User has unsubscribed from all feeds

TestSteps.StepAction:
**Check for the Participant Geo feed Profile** :

1.  _E.g. Open Internet Explorer and Press F12_
2.  Select the network tab and start recording
3.  Open the RSS feed "GEO"
4.  Select the GET Method
5.  Search for GEORSS
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
1.  Advanced feature opened
2.  Recording started
3.  GEO feed website opened
4.  GET Method selected
5.  GEORSS is within the response body

Tests.Name: Read/Write access to portal - SP5

TestCase.Name: Read/Write access to portal - SP5

TestSteps.StepAction:
Perform the following actions with a read-enabled user:

1. Open a web browser and connect to your own web portal
2. Log in to the portal
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
Expected outcome per step
1.  Instead of the content, a login page should be displayed
2.  The web page opens and displayed the stored file(s)/data

TestSteps.StepAction:
Perform the following actions with a read-enabled user:

1. Open a file from the web portal
2. Edit the file that has just been opened and try to save it
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
Expected outcome per step:
1. The file opens successfully
2. The file fails to save and the web portal displays an error indicating the failure to the user

TestSteps.StepAction:
Perform the following actions with a write-enabled user:
1. Open a web browser and connect to our own web portal
2. Log in to the portal
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
Expected outcome per step:
1.  Instead of the content, a login page should be displayed
2.  The web page opens and displayed the stored file(s)/data

TestSteps.StepAction:
Perform the following actions with a write-enabled user:

1. Open a file from the web portal
2. Edit the file that has just been opened and try to save it
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
Expected outcome per step:
1. The file opens successfully
2. The file successfully saves to the web portal while potentially showing the update time

Tests.Name: Protection of information - SP5

TestCase.Name: Protection of information - SP5

TestSteps.StepAction: The user, from the Testing Workstation, logs in and opens the WEB Browser.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: WEB Browser opens and the default local webpage is displayed.

TestSteps.StepAction:
The user navigates to the web portal from the MNP as written in the JMEI from the test Workstation.

Information up to NATO Restricted may be shared using anonymous access. There's no access to directories with classified files above NATO restricted.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The user will not be able to access directories with files that are classified as confidential or above.

TestSteps.StepAction: The user attempts to log in to the WEB Portal of the MNP by using their own domain credentials.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: User is able to access and login to the portal by using their own domain credentials.

TestSteps.StepAction:
User looks at available files to determine if there is a confidential or secret file available to them and opens the file.
.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The link to the file will be visible on the page and the file will open when the user selects the file.

Tests.Name: Web Hosting Profile: Web Content Profile - SP5

TestCase.Name: Web Hosting Profile: Web Content Profile - SP5

TestSteps.StepAction:
**Disable Java and flash player:**

1.  Open Java control panel
2.  Navigate to the security tab
3.  Uncheck "enable Java content in the browser"
4.  _E.g. for Edge_
5.  Select "Extensions", "Manage Extensions"
6.  When installed (shockwave Flash object) disable the Extensions
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
1.  Java control panel opens
2.  Security tab displayed
3.  Java content "unchecked" in browser
4.  Gear box displays options
5.  Manage Add-ons opens
6.  Shockwave flash object disabled when installed

TestSteps.StepAction:
**Check for Media type HTML**:

1.  User will log into a workstation and open a web browser.
2.  _E.g. for Edge_
3.  To open DevTools, right-click the webpage, and then select Inspect. Or, press Ctrl+Shift+I (Windows, Linux) or F12
4.  In DevTools, on the main toolbar, select the **Elements** tab. If that tab isn't visible, click the More tabs (More tabs icon) button, or else the More Tools (More Tools icon) button.
5.  Open the Participant web page
6.  Check for the "DOCTYPE html"
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
1.  Web browser open
2.  Dev tools opens
3.  Web page opens
4.  Media type plays content

TestSteps.StepAction:
**Inspect for Media type HTML**:

1.  Select the **Elements** tab within the Dev Tools
2.  Inspect the first line of the script for HTML5 compliance
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
1. Expert level opens 
2. Check that the first element = < ! D O C T Y P E html>

Tests.Name: Web Platform Profiles - SP5

TestCase.Name: Web Platform Profiles - SP5

TestSteps.StepAction:
**Check for USE TLS is enabled**: 1. Log into a workstation and open the browser 2. Find the **TLS** options for the browser 3. Make sure that the **TLS 1.0, 1.1, 1.2** are unchecked **and TLS 1.3 (mandatory)** is checked.

_Consumers and Providers SHALL support RFC 5246 - Transport Layer Security Protocol Version 1.2 (TLS1.2, Reference A)._ **_Consumers and Providers SHALL NOT support TLS Version 1.0 (Reference C) or 1.1 (Reference D)._** _Source: SIP for TLS SP3_



_Examples:_ 1. Enable TLS in Google Chrome 2. Open Google Chrome 3. Press Alt + f and click on settings 4. Select the Show advanced settings option 5. Scroll down to the Network section and click on Change proxy settings button 6. Now go to the Advanced tab 7. Scroll down to the Security category 8. Now check the boxes for your TLS version 9. Enable TLS in Edge 10. Go to Internet options in Windows 11. Open the Advanced tab 12. Scroll down to the TLS versions 13. Now check the boxes for your TLS version 14. Enforce TLS in Firefox 15. Open Firefox. 16. In the address bar, type about:config and press Enter. 17. In the Search field, enter TLS. find and double click the entry for security.tls.version.max. 18. E.g. Set the integer value to 4 to force a maximum protocol of TLS 1.3.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
1. Default web page will open.

2. The Settings are enabled or can be changed to the given parameters.

TestSteps.StepAction:
**Check for Web platform profiles**:

1.  Within the browser open the website using \[http://yourwebiste.\[your.domain\](\[object Object\])\]
2.  Click on the lock icon next to the search bar and verify the utilized TLS version
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
1. Website has upgrade the http to https://yourwebsite.[yourdomain]
2. The security popup window opens and shows the that site is depicted using TLSv1.3

Tests.Name: Secure Communications - SP5

TestCase.Name: Secure Communications - SP5

TestSteps.StepAction:
**From a workstation in your MNP, open a command prompt/terminal window and type the following:**

*   telnet \[WebServerOfMNP\]:\[443\] \[Enter\]

OR (alternative on Windows) open a PowerShell Window and type:

*   New-Object System.Net.Sockets.TcpClient("\[WebServer\]", 443)

OR any other similar tool available.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
Telnet connection is successfully established

1. **(telnet [WebServer] 443)**
2. Trying [WebServer]

**Connected** to [WebServer]

Escape character is '^]'.

PowerShel alternative:

Client              : System.Net.Sockets.Socket

Available           : 0

**Connected           : True**

Tests.Name: Logging of events within the portal - SP5

TestCase.Name: Logging of events within the portal - SP5

TestSteps.StepAction: Run the portal in order to ensure at least one successful start of of the application.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The portal starts and is accessible by a user.

TestSteps.StepAction:
As a system administrator, log on to the portal host and check for the existance of either a log folder (including a filled in log file) **or** run a command returning the current events on the web server.
_(The utilization of the method depends on the implementation of logging in your mail server)_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The log folder should show at least one log file with an entry or the command output returns logged information.

TestSteps.StepAction: As a user log into the portal.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The portal is opened and displays the frontpage.

TestSteps.StepAction:
The sysadmin checks the latest log entry using the method in step 2.

_For details see SREQ 81_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
A new logging entry is available and reflect at least the following information.

* User identifier


* User IP / target IP
* Date and time of activity
* Event (in this case login)

Tests.Name: Web Platform Profiles - SP5

TestCase.Name: Web Platform Profiles - SP5

TestSteps.StepAction:
**Check for USE TLS is enabled**: 1. Log into a workstation and open the browser 2. Find the **TLS** options for the browser 3. Make sure that the **TLS 1.0, 1.1, 1.2** are unchecked **and TLS 1.3 (mandatory)** is checked.

_Consumers and Providers SHALL support RFC 5246 - Transport Layer Security Protocol Version 1.2 (TLS1.2, Reference A)._ **_Consumers and Providers SHALL NOT support TLS Version 1.0 (Reference C) or 1.1 (Reference D)._** _Source: SIP for TLS SP3_



_Examples:_ 1. Enable TLS in Google Chrome 2. Open Google Chrome 3. Press Alt + f and click on settings 4. Select the Show advanced settings option 5. Scroll down to the Network section and click on Change proxy settings button 6. Now go to the Advanced tab 7. Scroll down to the Security category 8. Now check the boxes for your TLS version 9. Enable TLS in Edge 10. Go to Internet options in Windows 11. Open the Advanced tab 12. Scroll down to the TLS versions 13. Now check the boxes for your TLS version 14. Enforce TLS in Firefox 15. Open Firefox. 16. In the address bar, type about:config and press Enter. 17. In the Search field, enter TLS. find and double click the entry for security.tls.version.max. 18. E.g. Set the integer value to 4 to force a maximum protocol of TLS 1.3.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
1. Default web page will open.

2. The Settings are enabled or can be changed to the given parameters.

TestSteps.StepAction:
**Check for Web platform profiles**:

1.  Within the browser open the website using \[http://yourwebiste.\[your.domain\](\[object Object\])\]
2.  Click on the lock icon next to the search bar and verify the utilized TLS version
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
1. Website has upgrade the http to https://yourwebsite.[yourdomain]
2. The security popup window opens and shows the that site is depicted using TLSv1.3

Tests.Name: Spiral 5 - SMC - EVT - Patch Event

TestCase.Name: Spiral 5 - SMC - EVT - Patch Event

TestSteps.StepAction: The service provider system sends updated information about an Event to the endpoint of the service consumer system.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: A well-formed request in FMN SMC Event Management OpenAPI format was sent to the service consumer system

TestSteps.StepAction: The service provider system sends updated information about an Event to the endpoint of the subscriber system.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: A well-formed request in FMN SMC Event Management OpenAPI format was sent to the subscriber system

TestSteps.StepAction: The service consumer system responds to the information update and confirms the successful update of the Event in the response.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: A well-formed response in FMN SMC Event Management OpenAPI format was sent back to the requesting service provider system

TestSteps.StepAction: The subscriber system responds to the information update and confirms the successful update of the Event in the response.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: A well-formed response in FMN SMC Event Management OpenAPI format was sent back to the requesting service provider system

TestSteps.StepAction: The service provider system checks whether a valid response was received.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The received HTTP response code indicates successful update of the Event in the service consumer system.

TestSteps.StepAction: The service provider system checks whether a valid response was received.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The received HTTP response code indicates successful update of the Event in the subscriber system.

Tests.Name: Spiral 5 - SMC - SRQ - List Service Requests

TestCase.Name: Spiral 5 - SMC - SRQ - List Service Requests

TestSteps.StepAction: The Service Consumer's system queries a list of Services Request that meet a filter condition via the endpoint of the Service Provider's system.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: A well-formed request was sent

TestSteps.StepAction: The Service Provider's system responds to the query and sends the Service Requests that meet the filter conditions with all attributes in the response.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: A well-formed response was sent back

TestSteps.StepAction: The Service Consumer's system checks whether a valid response was received.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
*   The received HTTP response code indicates successful processing of the query request in the Service Provider's system
*   The content of the response is well-formed

Tests.Name: Spiral 5 - SMC - CHG - Add Attachment to Change

TestCase.Name: Spiral 5 - SMC - CHG - Add Attachment to Change

TestSteps.StepAction: The source system sends an Attachment for an existing Change to the endpoint of the target system.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: * A well-formed request in FMN SMC Change Management OpenAPI format was sent to the target system

TestSteps.StepAction: A well-formed response in FMN SMC Change Management OpenAPI format was sent back to the requesting source system
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The received HTTP response code indicates that the Attachment has been successfully added to the existing Change in the target system.

TestSteps.StepAction: The source system sends a notification of the change to all known subscribers to its Change Management API.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
* A change notification is sent to subscribing systems.
* The received HTTP response code indicates a successful update of the Change in the target system

Tests.Name: Spiral 5 - SMC - Check local DNS

TestCase.Name: Spiral 5 - SMC - Check local DNS

TestSteps.StepAction: List all different SMC endpoints from your own SMC system configuration.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: List consisting one or more fully qualified domain names (FQDNs).

TestSteps.StepAction: For each own SMC system FQDNs check the A record for the system in your own domain Please open a terminal window and type the following: nslookup -type=a \[FQDN\]\[Enter\] **_Please type the output of the command in the comment for the step_**
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
For each nslookup gets the A record back from your DNS service. Results should look like this (per FQDN) **nslookup smc.nato.int**
Server: 8.8.8.8 Address: 8.8.8.8
Non-authoritative answer: Name:  smc.nato.int Address: 152.152.31.120

Tests.Name: SATURN Waveform Configuration

TestCase.Name: SATURN Waveform Configuration

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the required configuration parameters required for the information exchange using the SATURN waveform.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the configuration parameters required to implement the information exchange using SATURN waveform.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN - Hailing detection value (e.g. Enabled or Disabled)
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN Hailing - Frequency
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN - T40 hopset
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN - Time of Day (TOD)
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN TOD - UHF TOD Transmit activate value
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN TOD UHF Transmit - TOD Format
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN TOD UHF Transmit - Frequency
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN TOD - Cold Start initialize and Cold Start - Operational Date
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN TOD - GNSS TOD Receive activate value
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN TOD UHF Receive - Frequency
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN TOD - Leap Second Correction value
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN - Word of Day (WOD) corresponding to the Transmission Security Key (TSK) for configuring SATURN frequency hopping and pseudo-random control of other waveform features including synchronization, interleaving etc
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN WOD - Operational/Training mode selection
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: (Operational mode only) The SMA has defined the SATURN WOD - Split Synchronisation, Break-in, Leap Second Correction and Simultaneous Monitoring selection
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for these fields

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN WOD - Hopset Type
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction:
The SMA has defined the SATURN - Secure Voice operation mode.

If Enabled, the SMA has also defined the SATURN Secure Voice - Encryption Mode and COMSEC Key
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN - Master selection
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

TestSteps.StepAction: The SMA has defined the SATURN - Net ID, hopset selection and Fullband/Subband Net selection values.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The JMEIs has the value for this field.

Tests.Name: TACSAT IW PTT Tactical Voice

TestCase.Name: TACSAT IW PTT Tactical Voice

TestSteps.StepAction: A PTT voice call is established by the Initiator within the TACSAT nodes in the satellite tactical coalition network.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The target TACSAT IW nodes on the network receive that transmission.

TestSteps.StepAction: A PTT voice call is established by the Initiator within the TACSAT nodes in the satellite tactical coalition network.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The target TACSAT IW nodes on the network receive that transmission.

TestSteps.StepAction: The Partners that received the PTT voice communication established by the Provider reply with another PTT voice transmission and acknowledge the reception of the first call.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The TACSAT IW node that established the first communication receives the acknowledges from the other TACSAT IW nodes.

TestSteps.StepAction: The Partners that received the PTT voice communication established by the Provider reply with another PTT voice transmission and acknowledge the reception of the first call.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The TACSAT IW node that established the first communication receives the acknowledges from the other TACSAT IW nodes.

TestSteps.StepAction: The initiator shall initiate voice multicast transmission (e.g PTT-pressed)
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The transmission of voice multicast is established with the receivers.

TestSteps.StepAction: The initiator shall initiate voice multicast transmission (e.g PTT-pressed)
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The transmission of voice multicast is established with the receivers.

Tests.Name: 4999: REPO-05591-Temporary disconnect from Mission Network

TestCase.Name: 4999: REPO-05591-Temporary disconnect from Mission Network

TestSteps.StepAction:
The **Initiator** provides at least two Battlespace Objects (BSO) on a Generic Overlay. _BSO # 1_ * Type: Vehicle * Name: XXX Veh Disconnect YY * Location: In your nation or an area assigned to you by the MN SMA _BSO # 2_ * Type: Military Unit * Name: XXX Unit Disconnect YY * Location: in your nation or an area assigned to you by the MN SMA
**Make the Generic Overlay available for the Target**
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
*   Objects and all its properties are visible in the Generic Overlay of the C2IS of the **Initiator**.
*   Generic Overlay is available for **Target.**

TestSteps.StepAction: **Target** consumes the Generic overlay.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Objects and all its properties are visible in the Generic Overlay of the C2IS of the **Target**.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Has determined the exact time the disconnect will occur.

Informs the **MN SMA** about the _Effective DateTime_ of the disconnect.

NOTE: for the tests this will be a matter of minutes but in reality could be something like "0800 on the 8th of July."
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The **MN SMA** received the _Effective Datetime_ of the disconnect.

TestSteps.StepAction:
**MN SMA**

Informs all MNP about the _Effective Datetime_ of the Targets disconnect
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: **Targets** are aware of the _Effective Datetime_ of the disconnect of the **Initiator**.

TestSteps.StepAction: **Initiator** disconnects from the network by shutting down the gateway or disconnecting the network
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
*   The **Initiator** endpoint are made unavailable to all **targets**.
*   **Initiator** is disconnected from the Mission Network.

TestSteps.StepAction:
**Initiator**

*   Modifies the name of the vehicle by changing the name to end in "-RENAMED".
*   Delete the unit.
*   Creates a new Facility with the name ending in "-NEW" and assign a location.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The new and modified objects are visible in C2IS of the **Initiator**; the unit is deleted.

TestSteps.StepAction: **Target** tries to consume the Generic Overlay .
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Gateway receives a timeout/error message or network unavailable message.

TestSteps.StepAction: **Initiator** re-connects to the network.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
**Initiator** is connected to the Mission Network.

**Initiator** connection endpoint made available to the **Target**.

TestSteps.StepAction: **Target** consumes the Generic Overlay.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
Objects and properties are visible in the Generic Overlay of the C2IS of the **Target:**

*   New Facility is visible
*   Unit is removed
*   Vehicle is renamed

TestSteps.StepAction: **Initiator** removes the remaining objects.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Objects removed at **Initiator**.

TestSteps.StepAction: **Target** consumes the Generic Overlay.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: All objects deleted at **Target**.

Tests.Name: Calendar sharing and functionalities via Web Hosting

TestCase.Name: Calendar sharing and functionalities via Web Hosting

TestSteps.StepAction: The provider either publishes himself his calendar to his webserver or ensures this is done by a backend system.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The iCAL object is available on the webserver.

'''VALIDATION'''

*   INTEROPERABILITY ISSUE when the object is not on the webserver

TestSteps.StepAction: The reader imports the calendars of the provider in his CUA and checks for the usage of https.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
1.  The calendar can be imported, visualized and the planned meeting is visible as 'busy'.
2.  The connection is established via https.

'''VALIDATION'''

*   MAX LIMITED SUCCESS when there is an issue with the DTG.
*   INTEROPERABILITY ISSUE issues with import/viewing the meeting.

TestSteps.StepAction: The provider reschedules the planned meeting (see preconditions) on the next day and ensures the calendar is republished.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The republishing of the calendar on the website is successful

'''VALIDATION'''
* INTEROPERABILITY ISSUE when the  object is not updated on the webserver

TestSteps.StepAction: The reader validates that the free/busy is updated and monitored correctly.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The updated DTG of the meeting is correctly reflected in the free/busy information of all users.

'''VALIDATION'''
* INTEROPERABILITY ISSUE issues with import/viewing the meeting.

TestSteps.StepAction: The provider sets permission for other users viewing/reading the calendar to „read only”.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
Only calendar owner can update his calendar.

'''VALIDATION'''

*   INTEROPERABILITY ISSUE when „read only” can not be set.

TestSteps.StepAction: The reader tries to update the planned meeting in the calendar.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The meeting can not be updated. 

'''VALIDATION'''
* INTEROPERABILITY ISSUE when the  meeting is updated.

Tests.Name: Calendar-event related functionalities

TestCase.Name: Calendar-event related functionalities

TestSteps.StepAction: The initiator prepares a meeting request and adds all involved parties as attendees to the event.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The user can successfully add participants to the meeting request.
Evidence shall show the event, the Day Time Group (DTG) with time zone and the list of participants

TestSteps.StepAction: The initiator sends out a meeting request to other users (attendees - see list in precondition). In the body, local language and all allowed character sets may be used.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The meeting request is sent out.

TestSteps.StepAction: The attendee receives a meeting request and it is processed by CUA as an event.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The user can see the meeting details and has the option to decide what to do regarding the meeting attendance.
Evidence shall show the event content and the list of participants

TestSteps.StepAction: The attendee validates all the meeting requests for the correct DTG. The Time zone is part of the event details.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The DTG of the received event shall correspond to the DTG defined by the event organizer.
Evidence shall show the content of the event, the DTG, and the time zone

TestSteps.StepAction: The attendee accepts the meeting request.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: A notification is sent out to the initiator (meeting organizer).

TestSteps.StepAction: The meeting organizer receives notifications regarding meeting attendance.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The initiator (meeting organizer) can see who will attending or not attending the meeting.
Evidence shall show the correct reception of the Event Attendee answer

TestSteps.StepAction: The attendee checks that the event is added in his calendar.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The event is properly placed in the calendar.
Evidence shall show that the calendar now contains the event.

TestSteps.StepAction: The initiator updates his meeting request (postponing event by 1 day).
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: A notification is sent to attendees.

TestSteps.StepAction: The attendee receives a meeting request update.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The calendar of the user is updated with the new DTG.
Evidence shall show the correct update in the event attendee calendar.

TestSteps.StepAction: The initiator cancels the event.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: A notification is sent to attendees.

TestSteps.StepAction: The attendees receive the cancel notification.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The event is cancelled and deleted from the user’s calendar.
Evidence shall show the cancellation of the event in the calendar

Tests.Name: Calendar sharing and functionalities via Email

TestCase.Name: Calendar sharing and functionalities via Email

TestSteps.StepAction: The provider publishes his calendar using a mail transfer agent.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The iCAL object sent and received through the email mediator.

'''VALIDATION'''

*   INTEROPERABILITY ISSUE when the object is received

TestSteps.StepAction: The reader imports the calendars of the provider in his CUA.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The calendar can be imported, visualized and the planned meeting is visible as 'busy'

'''VALIDATION'''
* MAX LIMITED SUCCESS when there is an issue with the DTG.
* INTEROPERABILITY ISSUE issues with import/viewing the meeting.

TestSteps.StepAction: The provider reschedules the planned meeting (see preconditions) for the next day and ensures the calendar is republished to the recipients.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The republishing of the calendar on the website is successful

'''VALIDATION'''

*   INTEROPERABILITY ISSUE when the object is not received with the update through the email mediator

TestSteps.StepAction: The reader validates that the "free/busy" is updated with the new schedule.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The updated DTG of the meeting is correctly reflected in the free/busy information of all users.

'''VALIDATION'''
* INTEROPERABILITY ISSUE issues with import/viewing the meeting.

Tests.Name: Ground-to-Air Information Exchange (IER-468)

TestCase.Name: Ground-to-Air Information Exchange (IER-468)

TestSteps.StepAction: WDA (e.g. tactical aircraft) initiates response by triggering the ground-to-air service by sending an appropriately configured J12.6 Target Sorting message based on parameters in ADatP-37.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Ground-to-Air Service is triggered to respond to the tactical aircraft.

TestSteps.StepAction: Ground-to-Air Service identifies the 5 (default value but configurable) closest friendly positions to the point of interest in the J12.6 message from the triggering aircraft and generates surveillance track messages for the identified positions. Ground-to-Air Service transmits identified friendly positions to Link 16 network via JREAP J3.x surveillance track messages.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Requesting aircraft receives and displays friendly track messages on Link 16 display.

Tests.Name: Ground-to-Air Information Exchange (IER-468)

TestCase.Name: Ground-to-Air Information Exchange (IER-468)

TestSteps.StepAction: WDA (e.g. tactical aircraft) initiates response by triggering the ground-to-air service by sending an appropriately configured J12.6 Target Sorting message based on parameters in ADatP-37.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Ground-to-Air Service is triggered to respond to the tactical aircraft.

TestSteps.StepAction: Ground-to-Air Service identifies the 5 (default value but configurable) closest friendly positions to the point of interest in the J12.6 message from the triggering aircraft and generates surveillance track messages for the identified positions. Ground-to-Air Service transmits identified friendly positions to Link 16 network via JREAP J3.x surveillance track messages.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Requesting aircraft receives and displays friendly track messages on Link 16 display.

Tests.Name: Remove Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Trust

TestCase.Name: Remove Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Trust

TestSteps.StepAction:
Remove the Federation Trust against MNP in the IdP Service.
**Example for ADFS:** 1\. Log in to the ADFS server. 2\. Open the **ADFS Management Console**
1\. Navigate to **Trust Relationships > Claims Provider Trusts**. 2\. Locate the trust for the other ADFS server. 3\. Right-click the trust and select **Delete**. 4\. Confirm the deletion.
1\. Navigate to **Trust Relationships > Relying Party Trusts**. 2\. Locate the trust for the other ADFS server. 3\. Right-click the trust and select **Delete**. 4\. Confirm the deletion.
**Example for KeyCloak:** 1\. Open your browser and go to the Keycloak Admin Console. 2\. Log in using your admin credentials.
1\. Navigate to the **Identity Providers** section. Select your realm in the admin console. Go to **Identity Providers** in the left-hand menu. 2\. Find the Identity Provider (IdP) you want to remove (e.g., the ADFS configuration). 3\. Click the trash icon or the **Delete** button to remove it. 4\. Confirm the deletion.
1\. Navigate to the **Clients** section. Select your realm in the admin console. Go to **Clients** in the left-hand menu. 2\. Find the client corresponding to the other system (e.g., the ADFS SP). 3\. Click the client name to open its configuration. 4\. Use the **Delete** button to remove it. 5\. Confirm the deletion.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Trust is removed from the IdP Service.

TestSteps.StepAction: Verify that you are **NOT** able to login to the MNPs Service Provider anymore.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Users are **NOT** able to connect to the MNPs Service Provider.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the **IdP Service is NOT available on HTTPS** anymore**.**
_NOTE! Remember that the port can be different based on the MNPs configuration. This should be stated in the JMEI._
**Example with PowerShell:** _Test-NetConnection -ComputerName <IdP Service Unique Identifier URL> -Port 443_
**Example with Curl:** curl -v _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_
**Example with Netcat:** nc -zv _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_ 443
**Example with Nmap:** nmap -p 443 _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: IdP Service is **NOT** responding on port 443.

Tests.Name: MNP Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Metadata

TestCase.Name: MNP Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Metadata

TestSteps.StepAction:
Download the MNPs Federation Metadata XML-file and open in your preferred text-editor.
**Example with ADFS:** _curl -o FederationMetadata.xml https://<adfs-server-domain>/FederationMetadata/2007-06/FederationMetadata.xml_
**Example with KeyCloak:** _curl -o keycloak\_metadata.xml https://<keycloak-server-domain>/auth/realms/<realm-name>/protocol/saml/descriptor_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata is successfully downloaded as an XML-file and readable.

TestSteps.StepAction: Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains **<IDPSSODescriptor>** and **<SPSSODescriptor>** with **protocolSupportEnumeration_\=_"urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:protocol"**
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata XML-file contains **<IDPSSODescriptor>** and **<SPSSODescriptor>.**

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains information about the **IdP Unique Identifier** defined in the JMEI.
**Example with ADFS:** _<EntityDescriptor entityID="https://idp.example.com/adfs/services/trust">_
**Example with KeyCloak:** _<EntityDescriptor entityID="https://<keycloak-server-domain>/auth/realms/<realm-name>/protocol/saml">_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata contains the **IdP Unique Identifier** defined in the JMEI within **<EntityDescriptor>.**

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains bindings for **HTTP-Redirect** within **SAML 2.0** **Binding**.
**Example with ADFS:** _<SingleSignOnService Binding="urn:oasis:names:tc:_**_SAML:2.0:bindings:HTTP-Redirect_**_" Location="https://idp.example.com/adfs/services/trust"/>_ _<SingleLogoutService Binding="urn:oasis:names:tc:_**_SAML:2.0:bindings:HTTP-Redirect_**_" Location="https://idp.example.com/adfs/services/trust"/>_
**Example with KeyCloak:** _<SingleSignOnService Binding="urn:oasis:names:tc:_**_SAML:2.0:bindings:HTTP-Redirect_**_" Location="https://keycloak.example.com/auth/realms/<realm-name>/protocol/saml"/>_ _<SingleLogoutService Binding="urn:oasis:names:tc:_**_SAML:2.0:bindings:HTTP-Redirect_**_" Location="https://idp.example.com/adfs/services/trust"/>_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata contains the **HTTP-Redirect** within **SAML 2.0** **Binding** within **<SingleSignOnService>** and **<SingleLogoutService>**

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains bindings for **HTTP-POST within SAML 2.0 Binding.**
**Example with ADFS:** _<SingleSignOnService Binding="urn:oasis:names:tc:_**_SAML:2.0:bindings/HTTP-POST_**_" Location="https://idp.example.com/adfs/services/trust"/>_
**Example with KeyCloak:** _<SingleSignOnService Binding="urn:oasis:names:tc:_**_SAML:2.0:bindings/HTTP-POST_**_" Location="https://keycloak.example.com/auth/realms/<realm-name>/protocol/saml"/>_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata contains the **HTTP-POST** within **SAML 2.0** **Binding** within **<SingleSignOnService>.**

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains the **Unique Identifier Claim** and as a minimum the **Mandatory** **Claims** defined in the JMEI.
**Example for ADFS:** _<RequestedAttribute Name="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress" NameFormat="urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:attrname-format:unspecified" />_
**Example for KeyCloak:** _<RequestedAttribute Name="email" NameFormat="urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:attrname-format:unspecified" />a_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata contains **Unique Identifier Claim** and as a minimum the **Mandatory Claims.**

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains the correct **Token-Signing Certificate.**
**_<KeyDescriptor use="signing">_** _<KeyInfo xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#">_ _<X509Data>_ _<X509Certificate>_ _MIICoTCCAYk…<trimmed\_certificate\_data>…==_ _</X509Certificate>_ _</X509Data>_ _</KeyInfo>_ _</KeyDescriptor>_
Copy the content inside <X509Certificate> and save it to a file (e.g., idp\_certificate.pem) with the following structure. _\-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----_ _MIICoTCCAYk…<certificate\_data>…==_ _\-----END CERTIFICATE-----_
Verify that the certificate is part of the Trust List for the Network.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata contains **Token-Signing Certificate** that is part of the Trust List for the Network within **<KeyDescriptor>**

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains the correct **Token-Encryption** **Certificate.**
**_<KeyDescriptor use="encryption">_** _<KeyInfo xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#">_ _<X509Data>_ _<X509Certificate>_ _MIICoTCCAYk…<trimmed\_certificate\_data>…==_ _</X509Certificate>_ _</X509Data>_ _</KeyInfo>_ _</KeyDescriptor>_
Copy the content inside <X509Certificate> and save it to a file (e.g., idp\_certificate.pem) with the following structure. _\-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----_ _MIICoTCCAYk…<certificate\_data>…==_ _\-----END CERTIFICATE-----_
Verify that the certificate is part of the Trust List for the Network.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata contains **Token-Encryption Certificate** that is part of the Trust List for the Network within **<KeyDescriptor>**

Tests.Name: MNP Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Metadata

TestCase.Name: MNP Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Metadata

TestSteps.StepAction:
Download the MNPs Federation Metadata XML-file and open in your preferred text-editor.
**Example with ADFS:** _curl -o FederationMetadata.xml https://<adfs-server-domain>/FederationMetadata/2007-06/FederationMetadata.xml_
**Example with KeyCloak:** _curl -o keycloak\_metadata.xml https://<keycloak-server-domain>/auth/realms/<realm-name>/protocol/saml/descriptor_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata is successfully downloaded as an XML-file and readable.

TestSteps.StepAction: Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains **<IDPSSODescriptor>** and **<SPSSODescriptor>** with **protocolSupportEnumeration_\=_"urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:protocol"**
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata XML-file contains **<IDPSSODescriptor>** and **<SPSSODescriptor>.**

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains information about the **IdP Unique Identifier** defined in the JMEI.
**Example with ADFS:** _<EntityDescriptor entityID="https://idp.example.com/adfs/services/trust">_
**Example with KeyCloak:** _<EntityDescriptor entityID="https://<keycloak-server-domain>/auth/realms/<realm-name>/protocol/saml">_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata contains the **IdP Unique Identifier** defined in the JMEI within **<EntityDescriptor>.**

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains bindings for **HTTP-Redirect** within **SAML 2.0** **Binding**.
**Example with ADFS:** _<SingleSignOnService Binding="urn:oasis:names:tc:_**_SAML:2.0:bindings:HTTP-Redirect_**_" Location="https://idp.example.com/adfs/services/trust"/>_ _<SingleLogoutService Binding="urn:oasis:names:tc:_**_SAML:2.0:bindings:HTTP-Redirect_**_" Location="https://idp.example.com/adfs/services/trust"/>_
**Example with KeyCloak:** _<SingleSignOnService Binding="urn:oasis:names:tc:_**_SAML:2.0:bindings:HTTP-Redirect_**_" Location="https://keycloak.example.com/auth/realms/<realm-name>/protocol/saml"/>_ _<SingleLogoutService Binding="urn:oasis:names:tc:_**_SAML:2.0:bindings:HTTP-Redirect_**_" Location="https://idp.example.com/adfs/services/trust"/>_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata contains the **HTTP-Redirect** within **SAML 2.0** **Binding** within **<SingleSignOnService>** and **<SingleLogoutService>**

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains bindings for **HTTP-POST within SAML 2.0 Binding.**
**Example with ADFS:** _<SingleSignOnService Binding="urn:oasis:names:tc:_**_SAML:2.0:bindings/HTTP-POST_**_" Location="https://idp.example.com/adfs/services/trust"/>_
**Example with KeyCloak:** _<SingleSignOnService Binding="urn:oasis:names:tc:_**_SAML:2.0:bindings/HTTP-POST_**_" Location="https://keycloak.example.com/auth/realms/<realm-name>/protocol/saml"/>_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata contains the **HTTP-POST** within **SAML 2.0** **Binding** within **<SingleSignOnService>.**

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains the **Unique Identifier Claim** and as a minimum the **Mandatory** **Claims** defined in the JMEI.
**Example for ADFS:** _<RequestedAttribute Name="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress" NameFormat="urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:attrname-format:unspecified" />_
**Example for KeyCloak:** _<RequestedAttribute Name="email" NameFormat="urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:attrname-format:unspecified" />a_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata contains **Unique Identifier Claim** and as a minimum the **Mandatory Claims.**

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains the correct **Token-Signing Certificate.**
**_<KeyDescriptor use="signing">_** _<KeyInfo xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#">_ _<X509Data>_ _<X509Certificate>_ _MIICoTCCAYk…<trimmed\_certificate\_data>…==_ _</X509Certificate>_ _</X509Data>_ _</KeyInfo>_ _</KeyDescriptor>_
Copy the content inside <X509Certificate> and save it to a file (e.g., idp\_certificate.pem) with the following structure. _\-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----_ _MIICoTCCAYk…<certificate\_data>…==_ _\-----END CERTIFICATE-----_
Verify that the certificate is part of the Trust List for the Network.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata contains **Token-Signing Certificate** that is part of the Trust List for the Network within **<KeyDescriptor>**

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation Metadata XML-file contains the correct **Token-Encryption** **Certificate.**
**_<KeyDescriptor use="encryption">_** _<KeyInfo xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#">_ _<X509Data>_ _<X509Certificate>_ _MIICoTCCAYk…<trimmed\_certificate\_data>…==_ _</X509Certificate>_ _</X509Data>_ _</KeyInfo>_ _</KeyDescriptor>_
Copy the content inside <X509Certificate> and save it to a file (e.g., idp\_certificate.pem) with the following structure. _\-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----_ _MIICoTCCAYk…<certificate\_data>…==_ _\-----END CERTIFICATE-----_
Verify that the certificate is part of the Trust List for the Network.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Metadata contains **Token-Encryption Certificate** that is part of the Trust List for the Network within **<KeyDescriptor>**

Tests.Name: Etablish Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Trust

TestCase.Name: Etablish Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Trust

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify the outgoing rules for the Federation Trust is against a specific MNP.
**Example for ADFS:** _Get-AdfsRelyingPartyTrust -Name "PartnerSP"_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The Federation Trust contains the list of defined Claims within the JMEI.
**Example for ADFS** _Look for Claims in IssuanceTransformRules._

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify the incoming rules for the Federation Trust is against a specific MNP.
**Example for ADFS:** _Get-AdfsClaimsProviderTrust -Name "PartnerIdP"_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The Federation Trust contains the list of defined Claims within the JMEI.
**Example for ADFS** Look for Claims in _AcceptanceTransformRules_.

TestSteps.StepAction:
**(Optional Step)**
You can simulate a token issuance to see the claims generated, which includes attributes from the external attribute store. Check if the attributes from the external attribute store are present in the claims.
**Example for ADFS:** _$upn = "testuser@example.com"_ _$rp = Get-AdfsRelyingPartyTrust -Name "<RelyingPartyName>"_ _$result = Test-AdfsServerToken -TargetRelyingParty $rp -UserPrincipalName $upn_ _$result.Claims_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Successfully simulated the generation of security token with claims.

Tests.Name: Inspect the Security Token with encrypted claims

TestCase.Name: Inspect the Security Token with encrypted claims

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation with MNP is configured to **encrypt claims** in the Security Token.
**Example for ADFS:** _Get-AdfsRelyingPartyTrust -Name "PartnerSP" | Select-Object Name, EncryptedClaims_ _(Get-AdfsRelyingPartyTrust -Name "PartnerSP").EncryptionCertificate | Select-Object Subject, Issuer, NotAfter_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The claims against MNP is configured to be encrypted.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Initiator open the browser and configure the browser to capture web-traffic. This might be slightly different between browsers:
**Example for Microsoft Edge:** _Open the Web Browser on your system_ _Navigate and find_ **_Developer Tools_**_._ _Navigate to the tab_ **_Network_** _Find and check_ **_Preserve log_** _to keep the logs between sessions._
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Browser is open and ready to capture web-traffic.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Navigate and start a login process on the MNPs Service Provider configured with the IdP Service.
**Example for ADFS:** _https://<adfs-server>/adfs/ls/idpinitiatedsignon.html_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Login was successfully completed.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Look for a **SAML Post** in the Developer Tools. Select the and then view the **Headers** tab at the bottom. Look for the **SAML Response** attribute that contains the Base64 encoded request Decode the Base64 encoded SAML Response to a readable XML-file.
**Example for Windows:** _certutil -decode encoded.txt decoded.txt_
**Example on Linux:** _base64 --decode encoded.txt > decoded.txt_
**Example with OpenSSL** _openssl base64 -d -in encoded.txt -out decoded.txt_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: A readable XML-file containing the content of the unencrypted Security Token (SAML) is present.
The Security Token is encrypted, and we are not able to identify any of the sensitive data (Example: Claims, Unique Identifier Claim etc..).

Tests.Name: Authentication end-to-end

TestCase.Name: Authentication end-to-end

TestSteps.StepAction: The user opens the web browser and navigate to the website (Service Provider) for the specific MNP.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Website for the specific MNP is accessible.

TestSteps.StepAction: On the website you should get the option to get redirected to your own IdP Service for login.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: User is redirected to own IdP Service.

TestSteps.StepAction: The user makes an authentication on his own IdP Service. Some systems might configure to use Single Sign-on (SSO) on the IdP Service, and therefore does not have to write the credentials manually.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: User authenticate successfully on the IdP Service.

TestSteps.StepAction: After the successfully authentication, the user is redirected back to the partners IdP Service, and at last the Website (Service Provider) of MNP. With the correct Claims the user should be logged into the website of the MNP.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: User is logged into the MNPs website using Web Authentication.

TestCase.Name: Inspect the Security Token without encrypted claims

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the Federation with MNP is configured to NOT encrypt claims to be able to inspect the Security Token.
**Example for ADFS:** _Get-AdfsRelyingPartyTrust -Name "PartnerSP" | Select-Object Name, EncryptedClaims_ _(Get-AdfsRelyingPartyTrust -Name "PartnerSP").EncryptionCertificate | Select-Object Subject, Issuer, NotAfter_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The claims against MNP is configured to be unencrypted.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Initiator open the browser and configure the browser to capture web-traffic. This might be slightly different between browsers:
**Example for Microsoft Edge:** _Open the Web Browser on your system_ _Navigate and find_ **_Developer Tools_**_._ _Navigate to the tab_ **_Network_** _Find and check_ **_Preserve log_** _to keep the logs between sessions._
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Browser is open and ready to capture web-traffic.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Navigate and start a login process on the MNPs Service Provider configured with the IdP Service.
**Example for ADFS:** _https://<adfs-server>/adfs/ls/idpinitiatedsignon.html_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Login was successfully completed.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Look for a **SAML Post** in the Developer Tools. Select the and then view the **Headers** tab at the bottom. Look for the **SAML Response** attribute that contains the Base64 encoded request Decode the Base64 encoded SAML Response to a readable XML-file.
**Example for Windows:** _certutil -decode encoded.txt decoded.txt_
**Example on Linux:** _base64 --decode encoded.txt > decoded.txt_
**Example with OpenSSL** _openssl base64 -d -in encoded.txt -out decoded.txt_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: A readable XML-file containing the content of the unencrypted Security Token (SAML) is present.

TestSteps.StepAction:
In the decoded Security Token. Verify that the Security Token used SAML 2.0 in the **<saml:Assertion>** block.
**Example:** _<saml:Assertion xmlns:saml="urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:assertion" Version="2.0"\\>_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Security Token contains the **<saml:Assertion>** block with the correct values from the example.

TestSteps.StepAction:
In the decoded Security Token. Verify the IdP Service that issued the token in the **<saml:Issuer>** block.
**Example for ADFS:** _<saml:Issuer>http://adfs.example.com/adfs/services/trust</saml:Issuer>_
**Example for KeyCloak:** _<saml:Issuer>https://keycloak.example.com/auth/realms/demo</saml:Issuer>_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Security Token contains the **<saml:Issuer>** block with the correct values from the example.
The Security Token contains the **<saml:Signature>** block and is digitally signed with the MNPs Token-Signed Certificate.
The Security Token contains the **<saml:Subject>** block and contents the Unique Identifier Claim from the JMEI.
The Security Token contains the **<saml:Conditions>** block and restricts the token to the MNPs.
The Security Token contains the **<saml:AttributeStatement>** block and the mandatory claims defined in the JMEI.

Tests.Name: Prerequisites before MNP Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Trust

TestCase.Name: Prerequisites before MNP Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Trust

TestSteps.StepAction:
Execute a **Forward Lookup** on the correct DNS-record (A or CNAME) for the **MNP Identity Provider Service.**
**Example for Windows:** _nslookup <Unique Identifier for IdP Service>_
**Example for Linux:** _dig A <Unique Identifier for IdP Service>_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Forward Lookup resolved the correct IP-address / alias for the MNP IdP Service and match the values defined in the JMEI.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the **MNP IdP Service is using HTTPS**, and HTTP is not available.
_NOTE! Remember that the port can be different based on the MNPs configuration. This should be stated in the JMEI._
**Example with PowerShell:** _Test-NetConnection -ComputerName <IdP Service Unique Identifier URL> -Port 443_ _Test-NetConnection -ComputerName <IdP Service Unique Identifier URL> -Port 80_
**Example with Curl:** curl -v _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_
**Example with Netcat:** nc -zv _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_ 443 nc -zv _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_ 80
**Example with Nmap:** nmap -p 443,80 _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: MNP IdP Service is responding on port 443. MNP IdP Service is **NOT** responding on port 80.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify the **MNP IdP Service Certificate** is valid and part of the Mission Trust List.
**Example with Certutil:** _certutil -urlcache http://example.com_ _certutil -url cert.cer_
**Example with PowerShell:** _$uri = "https://example.com"_ _$request = \[System.Net.HttpWebRequest\]::Create($uri)_ _$request.GetResponse() | select Certificate_
**Example with OpenSSL:** openssl s\_client -connect example.com:443 -showcerts openssl x509 -noout -text -in cert.pem
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The **MNP IdP Service Certificate** is valid and part of Trust List in Network.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify revocation of the **MNP IDP Service Certificate**
**Example with Certutil:** _certutil -verify -urlfetch C:\\certs\\mycertificate.cer_
**Example with PowerShell:** _$certificate = \[System.Net.HttpWebRequest\]::Create($uri).ServicePoint.Certificate_ _$chain = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Chain_ _$chain.Build($certificate)_ $chain.ChainStatus
**Example with OpenSSL:** openssl verify -crl\_check -crl\_download -CAfile chain.pem cert.cer
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The **MNP IdP Service Certificate** completed the revocation check successfully.

The Security Token contains the **<saml:Signature>** block and is digitally signed with the MNPs Token-Signed Certificate.

The Security Token contains the **<saml:Conditions>** block and restricts the token to the MNPs.
The Security Token contains the **<saml:AttributeStatement>** block and the mandatory claims defined in the JMEI.

Tests.Name: Authentication end-to-end

TestCase.Name: Authentication end-to-end

TestSteps.StepAction: The user opens the web browser and navigate to the website (Service Provider) for the specific MNP.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Website for the specific MNP is accessible.

TestSteps.StepAction: On the website you should get the option to get redirected to your own IdP Service for login.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: User is redirected to own IdP Service.

TestSteps.StepAction: The user makes an authentication on his own IdP Service. Some systems might configure to use Single Sign-on (SSO) on the IdP Service, and therefore does not have to write the credentials manually.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: User authenticate successfully on the IdP Service.

TestSteps.StepAction: After the successfully authentication, the user is redirected back to the partners IdP Service, and at last the Website (Service Provider) of MNP. With the correct Claims the user should be logged into the website of the MNP.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: User is logged into the MNPs website using Web Authentication.

Tests.Name: Remove Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Trust

TestCase.Name: Remove Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Trust

TestSteps.StepAction:
Remove the Federation Trust against MNP in the IdP Service.
**Example for ADFS:** 1\. Log in to the ADFS server. 2\. Open the **ADFS Management Console**
1\. Navigate to **Trust Relationships > Claims Provider Trusts**. 2\. Locate the trust for the other ADFS server. 3\. Right-click the trust and select **Delete**. 4\. Confirm the deletion.
1\. Navigate to **Trust Relationships > Relying Party Trusts**. 2\. Locate the trust for the other ADFS server. 3\. Right-click the trust and select **Delete**. 4\. Confirm the deletion.
**Example for KeyCloak:** 1\. Open your browser and go to the Keycloak Admin Console. 2\. Log in using your admin credentials.
1\. Navigate to the **Identity Providers** section. Select your realm in the admin console. Go to **Identity Providers** in the left-hand menu. 2\. Find the Identity Provider (IdP) you want to remove (e.g., the ADFS configuration). 3\. Click the trash icon or the **Delete** button to remove it. 4\. Confirm the deletion.
1\. Navigate to the **Clients** section. Select your realm in the admin console. Go to **Clients** in the left-hand menu. 2\. Find the client corresponding to the other system (e.g., the ADFS SP). 3\. Click the client name to open its configuration. 4\. Use the **Delete** button to remove it. 5\. Confirm the deletion.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The Federation Trust is removed from the IdP Service.

TestSteps.StepAction: Verify that you are **NOT** able to login to the MNPs Service Provider anymore.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Users are **NOT** able to connect to the MNPs Service Provider.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the **IdP Service is NOT available on HTTPS** anymore**.**
_NOTE! Remember that the port can be different based on the MNPs configuration. This should be stated in the JMEI._
**Example with PowerShell:** _Test-NetConnection -ComputerName <IdP Service Unique Identifier URL> -Port 443_
**Example with Curl:** curl -v _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_
**Example with Netcat:** nc -zv _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_ 443
**Example with Nmap:** nmap -p 443 _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: IdP Service is **NOT** responding on port 443.

Tests.Name: Prerequisites before MNP Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Trust

TestCase.Name: Prerequisites before MNP Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Trust

TestSteps.StepAction:
Execute a **Forward Lookup** on the correct DNS-record (A or CNAME) for the **MNP Identity Provider Service.**
**Example for Windows:** _nslookup <Unique Identifier for IdP Service>_
**Example for Linux:** _dig A <Unique Identifier for IdP Service>_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Forward Lookup resolved the correct IP-address / alias for the MNP IdP Service and match the values defined in the JMEI.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the **MNP IdP Service is using HTTPS**, and HTTP is not available.
_NOTE! Remember that the port can be different based on the MNPs configuration. This should be stated in the JMEI._
**Example with PowerShell:** _Test-NetConnection -ComputerName <IdP Service Unique Identifier URL> -Port 443_ _Test-NetConnection -ComputerName <IdP Service Unique Identifier URL> -Port 80_
**Example with Curl:** curl -v _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_
**Example with Netcat:** nc -zv _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_ 443 nc -zv _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_ 80
**Example with Nmap:** nmap -p 443,80 _<IdP Service Unique Identifier URL>_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: MNP IdP Service is responding on port 443. MNP IdP Service is **NOT** responding on port 80.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify the **MNP IdP Service Certificate** is valid and part of the Mission Trust List.
**Example with Certutil:** _certutil -urlcache http://example.com_ _certutil -url cert.cer_
**Example with PowerShell:** _$uri = "https://example.com"_ _$request = \[System.Net.HttpWebRequest\]::Create($uri)_ _$request.GetResponse() | select Certificate_
**Example with OpenSSL:** openssl s\_client -connect example.com:443 -showcerts openssl x509 -noout -text -in cert.pem
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The **MNP IdP Service Certificate** is valid and part of Trust List in Network.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify revocation of the **MNP IDP Service Certificate**
**Example with Certutil:** _certutil -verify -urlfetch C:\\certs\\mycertificate.cer_
**Example with PowerShell:** _$certificate = \[System.Net.HttpWebRequest\]::Create($uri).ServicePoint.Certificate_ _$chain = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Chain_ _$chain.Build($certificate)_ $chain.ChainStatus
**Example with OpenSSL:** openssl verify -crl\_check -crl\_download -CAfile chain.pem cert.cer
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The **MNP IdP Service Certificate** completed the revocation check successfully.

Tests.Name: Etablish Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Trust

TestCase.Name: Etablish Identity Provider (IdP) Federation Trust

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify the outgoing rules for the Federation Trust is against a specific MNP.
**Example for ADFS:** _Get-AdfsRelyingPartyTrust -Name "PartnerSP"_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The Federation Trust contains the list of defined Claims within the JMEI.
**Example for ADFS** _Look for Claims in IssuanceTransformRules._

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify the incoming rules for the Federation Trust is against a specific MNP.
**Example for ADFS:** _Get-AdfsClaimsProviderTrust -Name "PartnerIdP"_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The Federation Trust contains the list of defined Claims within the JMEI.
**Example for ADFS** Look for Claims in _AcceptanceTransformRules_.

TestSteps.StepAction:
**(Optional Step)**
You can simulate a token issuance to see the claims generated, which includes attributes from the external attribute store. Check if the attributes from the external attribute store are present in the claims.
**Example for ADFS:** _$upn = "testuser@example.com"_ _$rp = Get-AdfsRelyingPartyTrust -Name "<RelyingPartyName>"_ _$result = Test-AdfsServerToken -TargetRelyingParty $rp -UserPrincipalName $upn_ _$result.Claims_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Successfully simulated the generation of security token with claims.

Tests.Name: Verify all participants have received from SMA all relevant information to configure the JREAP Network

TestCase.Name: Verify all participants have received from SMA all relevant information to configure the JREAP Network

TestSteps.StepAction: Each MNP has provided all the required information to SMA
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: All information has been provided to SMA

TestSteps.StepAction: Verify SMA has produced an OPTASK Link, JMEI, or equivalent document with all the relevant information to establish a JREAP network
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The following information is contained in the documentation provided by the SMA

*   Time synchronization parameters, by default **UTC**
*   IP connectivity parameters by default **TCP**(TCP SRV assign PORT to Clients)
*   All the JRE processors have a unique**JRE ID**
*   All Active and Semi-Active Platform has a **JU ID**
*   All links between two platforms have a**Link ID** assigned
*   Active Platforms have a **track number**range assigned
*   All participants have assigned one or more JRE role by the SMA:
    *   **FJUG**\-> Active Forwarder Platforms
    *   **JRE JU** -> Active not Forwarder Platforms
    *   **JREU Hub**\- > Platform that distributes L16 traffic to two or more JRE units on the MN
    *   **JREU**\- > Semi-Active and Passive JREAP Platforms
    *   **Link 16 Display** -> Displays connected not integrated on FJUG, JRE JU, or JREU platforms

    *   **Link 16 Display** -> Displays connected not integrated on FJUG, JRE JU, or JREU platforms

Tests.Name: Verify all participants have received from SMA all relevant information to configure the JREAP Network

TestCase.Name: Verify all participants have received from SMA all relevant information to configure the JREAP Network

TestSteps.StepAction: Each MNP has provided all the required information to SMA
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: All information has been provided to SMA

TestSteps.StepAction: Verify SMA has produced an OPTASK Link, JMEI, or equivalent document with all the relevant information to establish a JREAP network
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome:
The following information is contained in the documentation provided by the SMA

*   Time synchronization parameters, by default **UTC**
*   IP connectivity parameters by default **TCP**(TCP SRV assign PORT to Clients)
*   All the JRE processors have a unique**JRE ID**
*   All Active and Semi-Active Platform has a **JU ID**
*   All links between two platforms have a**Link ID** assigned
*   Active Platforms have a **track number**range assigned
*   All participants have assigned one or more JRE role by the SMA:
    *   **FJUG**\-> Active Forwarder Platforms
    *   **JRE JU** -> Active not Forwarder Platforms
    *   **JREU Hub**\- > Platform that distributes L16 traffic to two or more JRE units on the MN
    *   **JREU**\- > Semi-Active and Passive JREAP Platforms
    *   **Link 16 Display** -> Displays connected not integrated on FJUG, JRE JU, or JREU platforms

Tests.Name: Verify FJUG (Active Forwarder) nodes have configured the systems according to OPTASKLINK / JMEI.

TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Systems are up and running with the JREAP configuration installed.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Provide pieces of evidence that equipment has configured the following parameters depending on the JRE Role:


*   **FJUG Active** 
    *   JRE ID
    *   Common Time Reference parameters
    *   Connection to the JRE Hub ( IP / TCP PORT)
    *   Link Id of the current connections
    *   JU ID ( Usually equal to the JRE ID)
    *   Verify connectivity with JITDS/MIDS Terminal
    *   Verify that the node is forwarding to L16 Network when connected to JITDS/MIDS Terminal

Tests.Name: Local Identity Provider (IdP) must add claims from local attribute store

TestCase.Name: Local Identity Provider (IdP) must add claims from local attribute store

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the IDP Service has configured an local attribute store that provides the claims defined in the JMEI.
**Example with ADFS:** _Test-AdfsAttributeStoreConnection -Name "<AttributeStoreName>"_ _Get-AdfsAttributeStore -Name "<AttributeStoreName>"_
**Example with KeyCloak:** _Select the Appropriate Realm_ _Navigate to User Federation_ _View Configured User Federation Providers_ _On the_ **_User Federation_** _page, you’ll see a list of configured providers_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The local attribute store is present and provides Claims.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the local attribute store is configured to harvest the **Unique** **Identifier** **Claim** and **Mandatory** (and Recommended/Optional) **Claims** defined in the JMEI.
**Example for ADFS:** _$AttributeStore = Get-AdfsAttributeStore -Name "<AttributeStoreName>"_ _Get-AdfsClaimsProviderTrust -Name $AttributeStore_
_Review the Claims listed in AcceptanceTransformRules. Example:_ _(Type == "[http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress](http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress)")_
**Example for KeyCloak:** _Navigate to Admin Console > User Federation._ _In the Client section. Select the client you want to verify._ _Go to the_ **_Mappers_** _tab and review attribute mappings._
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The local attribute store is configured to harvest **Unique** **Identifier** **Claim** and **Mandatory Claims** defined in the JMEI.

Tests.Name: Local Identity Provider (IdP) must log authentication attempts

TestCase.Name: Local Identity Provider (IdP) must log authentication attempts

TestSteps.StepAction: User attempts authentication on IdP.
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: Authentication process works.

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the IdP Service logged the user authentication attempt.
Event logs must include, as a minimum: user authentication attempts; and records of issued tokens, such as identification of the Relying Party (url), of Service Consumer (IP address) and the user identifier provided in the token (account attempting to use the service).
**Example for ADFS:** _Set-AdfsProperties -LogLevel Verbose_ _Set-AdfsProperties -AuditLevel Verbose_
_Get-WinEvent -FilterHashtable @{LogName='Security';Id=411} | Select-Object -First 20 | Format-List_
_Open_ **_Event Viewer_**_._ _Navigate to_ **_Applications and Services Logs_** _\\>_ **_AD FS_** _\\>_ **_Admin_**_._ _Look for events related to claim issuance._
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: The IdP Service is logging user authentication attempts with atleast the minimum requirements.

Tests.Name: Local Identity Provider (IdP) must use HTTPS

TestCase.Name: Local Identity Provider (IdP) must use HTTPS

TestSteps.StepAction:
Verify that the **IDP Service is using HTTPS**, and HTTP is not available.
_NOTE! Remember that the port can be different based on the MNPs configuration. This should be stated in the JMEI._
**Example with PowerShell:** _Test-NetConnection -ComputerName <IDP Service Unique Identifier URL> -Port 443_ _Test-NetConnection -ComputerName <IDP Service Unique Identifier URL> -Port 80_
**Example with Curl:** curl -v _<IDP Service Unique Identifier URL>_
**Example with Netcat:** nc -zv _<IDP Service Unique Identifier URL>_ 443 nc -zv _<IDP Service Unique Identifier URL>_ 80
**Example with Nmap:** nmap -p 443,80 _<IDP Service Unique Identifier URL>_
TestSteps.ExpectedOutcome: IDP Service is responding on port 443. IDP Service is **NOT** responding on port 80.
